newsitem.title: THAILAND: Unocal group signs Thai gas sales deal.
newsitem.headline: Unocal group signs Thai gas sales deal.

text.p: A consortium led by Unocal Corp of the U.S. said on Monday it had formally signed the first gas sales agreement with Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) for stage one of Thailand's Independent Power Producers programme.

Under the previously-announced deal, PTT will suppply Independent Power (Thailand) Co Ltd (IPT) -- formed by subsidiaries of Unocal, Westinghouse and the semi-government Thai Oil -- with 120 million cubic feet per day of natural gas for IPT to use as primary fuel for its power plant for 25 years.
The supply will be delivered via the gas pipeline for the gas separation plant in Rayong, Thailand to the IPT power plant in Chonburi, IPT said in a statement.

The Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) also signed a deal with PTT on Monday. Under its Master IPP Program agreement, EGAT will guarantee the minimum take of gas to be purchased from PTT by the four independent power producers.
EGAT will also redirect sales of gas which any IPP cannot take from PTT during plant shutdowns to another IPP or to EGAT's own facilities, the statement said.
Thai Oil Co Ltd's Thaioil Power Co Ltd has a 56 percent stake in IPT while Unocal Asia-Pacific Ventures Ltd has 24 percent and Westinghouse Electric SA has a 20 percent share.
IPT, which signed a power purchase agreement with EGAT in February, expects to begin construction on its 9.6 billion baht ($369.2 million) natural-gas fired combined cycle plant in May.
IPT was the first to sign its power purchase agreement with EGAT, and will be the first independent producer to begin selling electricity to the state agency.

The IPP program is meant to help EGAT meet growing demand for power. PTT said combined demand for natural gas as fuel for the country's electricity generation is expected to reach 2,400 million cubic feet per day in 2001.
